thread.title: Senex ‘prudent’ as Cooper, Surat basin projects ramp up | Business News | Business and Finance News | |
thread.title_full: Senex ‘prudent’ as Cooper, Surat basin projects ramp up | Business News | Business and Finance News | | The Advertiser

author: VALERINA CHANGARATHIL
title: Senex ‘prudent’ as Cooper, Surat basin projects ramp up | Business News | Business and Finance News | |
text:
A MATERIAL fall in crude prices led to a 32 per cent decline in full year revenues of Cooper Basin oil and gas producer Senex Energy.
The mid-tier company reported total revenues of $115.9 million - a result boosted by a 6 per cent gain in the June quarter.
Capital expenditure for FY15 came in at $82.2 million, down 47 per cent from the previous year in line with revised guidance of between $80 million and $85 million.
Senex revised its capital expenditure guidance during FY15 from up to $120 million in response to the expected decrease in full year revenues as a result of volatile energy market conditions.
Net production in the June quarter was 0.32 million barrels of oil equivalent (mmboe), down from 0.43 mmboe in the previous corresponding period.
The average realised oil price was $88 per barrel for the full year.
For the full-year, net production was 1.39 mmboe, a modest 1 per cent increase on the previous year and in line with revised guidance of between 1.36 mmboe and 1.41 mmboe.
“We will prioritise projects and protect our balance sheet, managing director Ian Davies told analysts.”
“(Senex) made a prudent and rapid response to the changed oil price environment during FY15, with the capital program reduced and high graded, operating savings implemented, and hedging put in place for H2 FY15 and FY16.
“In the current environment, it is defer, defer, defer unfortunately.”
Senex said it entered the new financial year in a “strong financial position” with $49 million in cash reserves and $80 million of undrawn debt.
Mr Davies said substantial progress had been made on the Western Surat Gas project in FY15, which he described as a “good opportunity in an LNG feed area”.
“(It’s) our most material, near term gas project.”
Senex has completed an initial engineering concept select study for surface facility design and will enter into a the Front End Engineering and Design (FEED) stage during FY16.
“Senex continues to plan for submission of an Environment Impact Statement to the Queensland
Government in mid-2016.”
In the Cooper Basin, Senex and joint venture partner Origin Energy continued to explore “a material unconventional gas opportunity” with a plan to drill four wells in FY16.
Senex shares were trading two per cent higher on the update - but the price is down significantly from the 70c at the same time last year.
Senex is backed by major shareholder Sentient, but has been on analysts’ radar along with other Cooper Basin companies attracting major investors.
Australian billionaire Kerry Stokes has built a near 20 per cent stake in SA oil and gas producers Beach Energy and Drillsearch through Seven Group Holdings in the past few months.
valerina.changarathil@news.com.au
